authorProfile.name: Emma Roberts
authorProfile.headline: CTO at TechCorp | Building scalable systems

content.postText:
After 18 months of scaling our platform from 10K to 1M users, here are the 7 lessons I wish I'd known from day one.

Thread on architecture decisions, team structure, and what we got wrong.

1/ Start with observability, not monitoring. We spent months debugging issues that would have been obvious with proper tracing. Invest in OpenTelemetry from day one.

2/ Your database will be the bottleneck. Always. We moved to read replicas too late. Plan for this early.

3/ Team topology matters more than tech stack. Conway's Law is real. Organize teams around business capabilities, not technical layers.

4/ Don't pre-optimize for scale you don't have. We over-engineered early and paid the complexity tax for years.

5/ Feature flags are essential, not optional. They saved us countless times during incidents.

6/ On-call rotations need structure. Without proper runbooks and escalation paths, people burn out.

7/ Communication scales harder than code. Invest in async communication patterns and documentation.

What lessons would you add?
